Expert testimonies: The expert's verdict includes statements from medical experts such as Davidson Hamer and Richard Watanabe, who both refute the claim that having a flu shot in the last 3-5 years would result in a positive COVID-19 test. Their expertise adds credibility to the debunking of the claim.
Scientific knowledge: The experts provide scientific explanations to counter the claim. Davidson Hamer explains that coronaviruses and influenza viruses have different antigenic structures, indicating that there would be no cross-reaction between the two vaccines. This scientific understanding supports the conclusion that the claim is false.
Lack of evidence: Richard Watanabe points out that there is no evidence to suggest that the novel coronavirus existed in humans before last year. Therefore, antibodies against the virus could not have been present in previous flu shots. This lack of evidence further discredits the claim.
Consensus among fact: checkers: The expert's verdict mentions that several other fact-checkers have also investigated the claim and reached the same conclusion that a flu shot cannot result in a false positive for COVID-19. This consensus among fact-checkers adds weight to the debunking of the claim.
